Name: Diclofop-methyl
Description: Methyl 2-[4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)phenoxy]propanoate is a methyl ester resulting from the formal condensation of the carboxylic acid group of 2-[4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)phenoxy]propanoic acid with methanol. It is an aromatic ether, a dichlorobenzene, a diether and a methyl ester.

plant_translocations.content: Retention, absorption, translocation, and volatility of foliarly applied diclofop-methyl {methyl 2-[4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy) phenoxy] propanoate} were compared in barnyardgrass [Echinochloa crus-galli (L.) Beauv.], a susceptible grass; proso millet (Panicum miliaceum L.), a moderately susceptible grass; longspine sandbur [Cenchrus longispinus (Hack.) Fern.], a tolerant grass; and soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr. ‘Hark’] and cucumber (Cucumis sativus L. ‘Green Star’), both tolerant broadleaf plants. On a jug/plant basis, the order of diclofop-methyl spray retention was cucumber > soybean > proso millet > longspine sandbur = barnyardgrass. On a μg/mg dry weight basis, proso millet retained 3 to 10 times more diclofop-methyl than all other species. One day after treatment (DAT), absorption of 14C-diclofopmethyl was 14 to 18% less in longspine sandbur than in the other species, 3 DAT absorption in cucumber was 8 to 14% greater than in the other species, and 5 DAT absorption in soybean was 3 to 12% less than in other species. Translocation of 14C-diclofop-methyl did not differ among species, with 98% of the applied radioactivity located in the treated leaf. An average of 11% of radioactivity applied to the surface of intact, living plants and excised, dried leaves of cucumber, soybean, and barnyardgrass, as well as glass cover slips, was lost by evaporation. None of the parameters measured showed differences large enough to be implicated as primary selectivity mechanisms.
plant_translocations.reference: Boldt, P. F., & Putnam, A. R. (1980). Selectivity mechanisms for foliar applications of diclofop-methyl. I. Retention, absorption, translocation, and volatility. Weed Science, 28(5), 474-477.

method.Test Plant: Annual grasses, soybean, and cucumber plants were used.
method.Apply Location: Foliar application on adaxial leaf surface
method.Plant Grown Condition: Plants were grown in a greenhouse at 30°C day/20°C night (±3°C), 30-60% relative humidity, with supplemental metal halide lighting at 842 μE/m2/s intensity and 16-hr photoperiod. They were planted in 20-cm diameter styrofoam pots with sand:peat:soil (1:1:1, v/v/v) potting medium. Plants were alternately surface-watered and sub-irrigated until treatment, then only sub-irrigated. 200 ml of 22.5% N-P2O5-K2O water-soluble fertilizer solution (2 g/L) was applied weekly.
method.Chemical Preparation: Diclofop-methyl was used. For retention studies, diclofop-methyl was diluted with distilled water to 11.5 μM solution containing 0.03 μCi in 25 μl applied as 0.5 μl droplets.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: At 10-14 days old (3 leaves for annual grasses, unifoliate for soybean, first true leaf for cucumber), plants were sprayed with diclofop-methyl, then 25 μl of the 11.5 μM radioactive solution was applied as 0.5 μl droplets to the adaxial leaf surface.
method.Other Information: Retention was assessed by washing plant surfaces with 50% methanol at 1, 3 and 5 days after treatment (DAT) and quantifying radioactivity in leaf washes and combusted foliage by liquid scintillation spectrometry. Percent absorption was calculated from radioactivity data. Replicates were not mentioned.

plant_translocations.result: [{"Plant": "Barnyardgrass", "Days after application": 1, "Absorption (%)": 55}, {"Plant": "Barnyardgrass", "Days after application": 3, "Absorption (%)": 65}, {"Plant": "Barnyardgrass", "Days after application": 5, "Absorption (%)": 71}, {"Plant": "Proso millet", "Days after application": 1, "Absorption (%)": 53}, {"Plant": "Proso millet", "Days after application": 3, "Absorption (%)": 69}, {"Plant": "Proso millet", "Days after application": 5, "Absorption (%)": 75}, {"Plant": "Longspine sandbur", "Days after application": 1, "Absorption (%)": 37}, {"Plant": "Longspine sandbur", "Days after application": 3, "Absorption (%)": 64}, {"Plant": "Longspine sandbur", "Days after application": 5, "Absorption (%)": 75}, {"Plant": "Soybean", "Days after application": 1, "Absorption (%)": 51}, {"Plant": "Soybean", "Days after application": 3, "Absorption (%)": 63}, {"Plant": "Soybean", "Days after application": 5, "Absorption (%)": 68}, {"Plant": "Cucumber", "Days after application": 1, "Absorption (%)": 53}, {"Plant": "Cucumber", "Days after application": 3, "Absorption (%)": 77}, {"Plant": "Cucumber", "Days after application": 5, "Absorption (%)": 80}]

plant_translocations.content: Oat (Avena sativa L. ‘Elgin′) and soybean (Glycine max L. ‘Evans′) were treated with 14C-diclofop-methyl {methyl ester of 2-[4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)phenoxy] propionic acid]} or 14C-diclofop alone or in combination with 2,4-D [(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)acetic acid] or bentazon [3-isopropyl-1H-2,1,3-benzothiadiazin-4(3H)-one 2,2-dioxide] and 14C-2,4-D alone or in combination with diclofop-methyl or diclofop. More radioactivity was recovered in the treatment zone after 14C-diclofop-methyl applications, alone or in combination, than after similar 14C-diclofop treatments in oat and soybean. Basipetal movement of radioactivity was 4 and 1% and acropetal movement was 1 and 4% in oat and soybean, respectively, regardless of the diphenyl ether treatment or time. Addition of 2,4-D or bentazon did not reduce translocation of radioactivity from 14C-diclofop-methyl treatments in either plant species. Basipetal movement of radioactivity from 14C-diclofop-methyl was greater than from 14C-diclofop in both oat and soybean. The addition of diclofop-methyl or diclofop did not affect the pattern or amount of 14C-2,4-D radioactivity translocated. In oats, radioactivity appeared to accumulate within the intercalary meristematic region with 14C-2,4-D and 14C-diphenyl-ether applications. Diclofop-methyl at 1 kg/ha applied either to an entire oat plant at the three-leaf stage or the apical meristemic region resulted in plant mortality. The extent to which transport contributes to diclofop-methyl efficacy is questioned.
plant_translocations.reference: Hall, C., Edgington, L. V., & Switzer, C. M. (1982). Translocation of different 2, 4-D, bentazon, diclofop, or diclofop-methyl combinations in oat (Avena sativa) and soybean (Glycine max). Weed Science, 30(6), 676-682.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Plants were grown in silica sand in 225 ml styrofoam cups and watered as required with half-strength Hoagland's solution. They were maintained in a growth room with 22.5±1°C day temperature, 65±2% relative humidity during day, and 19±1°C, 58±2% relative humidity at night with 16-hr photoperiod provided by cool-white fluorescent plus incandescent lights at 290 μE/m2/s intensity.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-diclofop-methyl (6.21 μCi/μmol, uniformly labeled in the dioxyphenyl ring, 99% pure), 14C-diclofop (6.17 μCi/μmol, uniformly labeled in the dioxyphenyl ring, 99% pure), Technical grade 2,4-D (99% pure), Bentazon (99% pure).Solutions were made in 50% aqueous ethanol.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: On 15-day old plants, 10 μl droplets were applied to adaxial surface of lower portion of unifoliate soybean leaf or mid-portion of second oat leaf at following rates:3.7 x 10^-3 μmol 14C-diclofop or 14C-diclofop-methyl alone.
method.Other Information: The study had a 3-factor analysis of covariance design with 3 time levels, 2 herbicidal formulation levels, 3 herbicide combination levels, and 5 replicates. Total recovered radioactivity was used as the covariate.
